block.p: The staff of the New York State Department of Public Service agreed with Con Edison and several consumer groups yesterday on a proposal to reduce electricity rates by up to 17.3 percent, and recommended that the state approve Con Ed's plan to merge with Northeast Utilities of New England.

The staff of the New York State Department of Public Service agreed with Con Edison and several consumer groups yesterday on a proposal to reduce electricity rates by up to 17.3 percent, and recommended that the state approve Con Ed's plan to merge with Northeast Utilities of New England.
The proposal now goes to the Public Service Commission, which meets on Nov. 9. It was negotiated after high bills over the summer angered many Con Ed customers.

Under the proposal, the reductions would be phased in through March 31, 2002. They would amount to 17.3 percent for residential customers and small and medium-sized commercial customers, and 13.7 percent for large commercial customers.

But Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer said he opposed the proposal. ''We are not opposed to a rate reduction,'' he said, ''but they continue to give Con Ed a pass-through on incremental costs of Con Ed's purchase of energy.''
